block.p: FLUSHING Jazz First Lady Has Four-Month Term in Office

Often called the first lady of jazz, the pianist Mary Lou Williams (1910-1981) is being celebrated in an exhibit that will tour nationally after a four-month run at Flushing Town Hall. The show is organized chronologically from Williams's childhood to her vaudeville and swing years to her efforts to save the legacy of jazz.

Manuscript scores, scrapbooks, personal effects, photographs and paintings, of and by Williams, will be displayed. There will also be a symposium, two concerts and a film screening throughout the fall.

''Mary Lou Williams: In Her Own Right''; Thursday through Dec. 31; Monday through Friday, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m., Saturday and Sunday noon to 5 p.m.; Flushing Town Hall, Northern Boulevard and Linden Place, Flushing; free; information and full schedule, (718) 463-7700.
SNUG HARBOR Artists Take a Stand On the Fence

Local artists will put their talent on the fence at Staten Island's oldest outdoor art show, the 50th Annual Fence Show. It be held today along the wrought-iron fence of the Snug Harbor Cultural Center (last year's is pictured below). Many of the more than 80 artists who will be participating will be on hand to discuss their art, all of which is for sale.
There will be paintings, drawings, photographs and work in other mediums. Space is still available for artists interested in exhibiting. They may call for information on rates and registration.
50th Annual Fence Show; today, 11 a.m. to 4 p.m.; along Snug Harbor Road and Kissel Avenue; free; (718) 727-1135.
BEDFORD-STUYVESANT Cultural Identity Via Multimedia Diversity

The work of six emerging multimedia artists of African-American descent who experiment with the creative process to create cultural identity are on display at the Skylight Gallery of the Bedford-Stuyvesant Restoration Corporation. The show, ''Year 2000 Challenge Art Exhibit,'' is being put on by the Restoration Corporation's Center for Art and Culture. The artists are Dirk Joseph, Weldon Ryan, Kimberly Becoat, Kevin Davis, Javaki Steptoe and Jennifer Jarrell.

Ms. Jarrell, perhaps the most experimental of the group, writes that she ''morphs plants, animals and humans'' in her sewn canvas pieces to meld the dimensions of time and space. (The one shown below is titled ''Creamy Hairdo.'')

''Year 2000 Challenge Art Exhibit''; through Oct. 28, Tuesday through Friday, 11 a.m. to 7 p.m., Saturday, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Skylight Gallery, 1368 Fulton Street near Nostrand Avenue, Brooklyn; suggested donation $2; (718) 636-6976.

PERP PORTRAITS -- Sketches from the trials of Sante and Kenneth Kimes and of Andrew Goldstein by a mother-daughter team, Shirley and Andrea Shepard, are on view in the lobby of John Jay College of Criminal Justice; the artists have included images from their front-row seats at trials in each borough; through Sept. 29, Monday through Friday, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.; 445 West 59th Street, near 10th Avenue; free; (212) 237-8698.

STREET CHURCH -- The street preachers who have made Broadway their open-air church are captured in ''The Gods of Times Square,'' a documentary film that was shot over six years by Richard Sandler; it is being shown at the Makor Jewish Center as part of the ''Reel Jews'' series; Tuesday 7:30 p.m. and 9:30 p.m.; 35 West 67th Street, near Central Park West; $8; (212) 601-1000.

DISHES AND SQUISHES -- In a street fair with above-average fare, 30 restaurants will sell samples of food and drink in the fourth annual Dine Around Downtown, sponsored in part by the Downtown Alliance; participants in a grape stomp can take home a bottle of wine; Tuesday, (rain date Wednesday) 11 a.m. to 3 p.m.; Austin J. Tobin Plaza of World Trade Center (near Church and Dey Streets); admission free; servings range from $3 to $5; (212) 835-2789.
